Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: A serious conflict with teammates is threatening the mentee’s deliverable timeline.
Expectation2: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation2: An automated compliance system flags any minute of unscheduled downtime for possible disciplinary action.
Story: I stared at my screen, the chat window with my mentor blinking insistently. My team was at each other’s throats, and our project deadline was slipping through our fingers. I knew I was supposed to reach out to my mentor as soon as problems arose, but my shift as a telemarketer was in full swing. The compliance system tracked every second, and if I took an unscheduled break—even just to send a quick message—I risked being flagged. My supervisor had warned me: one more infraction, and I’d be written up. But if I didn’t tell my mentor about the conflict, I’d be letting my team down and possibly sabotaging our project. My heart pounded as I weighed the risks, feeling the pressure from both sides. I hovered over the “send” button, torn between my responsibility to my mentor and the strict rules of my telemarketing job, knowing that whatever I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
